verses.text: So Joseph went and told Pharaoh, 'My father and my brothers, with their flocks and their herds and all they possess, have come from the land of Canaan and are now in the land of Goshen.'
verses.comment: Joseph acts as an intercessor between his family and Pharaoh, foreshadowing the mediatorial role seen in later biblical figures. Joseph's faithfulness is reminiscent of the obedient Son.

verses.text: And from among his brothers he took five men and presented them before Pharaoh.
verses.comment: Presenting a select group before the king reflects the theme of being chosen and set apart, a pattern repeated in the calling of apostles (Mark 3:13-14).

verses.text: Pharaoh said to his brothers, 'What is your occupation?' And they answered Pharaoh, 'Your servants are shepherds, both we and our fathers.'
verses.comment: Shepherd imagery is powerful throughout Scripture, pointing ultimately to Christ as the Good Shepherd (John 10:11).

verses.text: They said to Pharaoh, 'We have come to sojourn in the land, for there is no pasture for your servants' flocks, because the famine is severe in the land of Canaan. Now, please let your servants dwell in the land of Goshen.'
verses.comment: Their plea to dwell as sojourners echoes Israel's future situations and the motif of God's people as pilgrims (Heb. 11:13).

verses.text: Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, 'Your father and your brothers have come to you.'
verses.comment: Pharaoh’s recognition of Joseph’s family is significant, showing Joseph’s elevated status and favor.

verses.text: 'The land of Egypt is before you. Settle your father and your brothers in the best of the land. Let them dwell in the land of Goshen, and if you know any able men among them, put them in charge of my livestock.'
verses.comment: Bestowing the 'best of the land' suggests grace and blessing—prefiguring how God’s people receive blessings not due to their own merit but through divine election.

verses.text: Then Joseph brought in Jacob his father and presented him before Pharaoh, and Jacob blessed Pharaoh.
verses.comment: The theme of blessing flows from the elder patriarch to the king, showing the spiritual authority associated with the people of God.

verses.text: And Pharaoh said to Jacob, 'How many are the days of the years of your life?'
verses.comment: The phrase underscores respect for age and wisdom, themes important in biblical leadership and tradition (Lev. 19:32).

verses.text: And Jacob said to Pharaoh, 'The days of the years of my sojourning are one hundred thirty years. Few and evil have been the days of the years of my life, and they have not reached the days of the years of the lives of my fathers in the days of their sojourning.'
verses.comment: Jacob recognizes the fleeting nature of life, a reminder of the need for humility before God.

verses.text: And Jacob blessed Pharaoh and went out from the presence of Pharaoh.
verses.comment: Jacob’s blessing is significant, indicating that those with spiritual promises bear authority over even earthly powers.

verses.text: Then Joseph settled his father and his brothers and gave them a possession in the land of Egypt, in the best of the land, in the land of Rameses, as Pharaoh had commanded.
verses.comment: The best land given to Israel’s family looks ahead to the promise of future inheritance for God’s people.

verses.text: And Joseph provided food for his father, his brothers, and all his father's household, according to the number of their children.
verses.comment: Joseph’s provision is a prefigurement of Christ’s care for His Church, providing for all according to their needs (Mark 6:41-43).

verses.text: Now there was no food in all the land, for the famine was very severe, so that the land of Egypt and the land of Canaan became exhausted because of the famine.
verses.comment: The severe famine contrasts with the abundance God’s chosen receive, echoing motifs in Psalm 37:19.

verses.text: And Joseph gathered up all the money that was found in the land of Egypt and in the land of Canaan as payment for the grain they bought, and Joseph brought the money into Pharaoh's house.
verses.comment: Joseph’s wise administration reflects stewardship, which is later echoed in teachings on stewardship over the Church and its resources (Luke 16:1-9).

verses.text: When the money was all spent in the land of Egypt and in the land of Canaan, all the Egyptians came to Joseph and said, 'Give us food! Why should we die before your eyes? For our money is gone!'
verses.comment: The running out of money emphasizes total reliance on God’s provision and the authority invested in His chosen servant.

verses.text: And Joseph said, 'Give your livestock, and I will give you food in exchange for your livestock, if your money is gone.'
verses.comment: Joseph institutes a system of exchange, showing wisdom in governance.

verses.text: So they brought their livestock to Joseph, and Joseph gave them food in exchange for their horses, flocks, herds, and donkeys. He supplied them with food in exchange for all their livestock that year.
verses.comment: Sacrificing livestock for life echoes the coming sacrificial system, culminating in the perfect sacrifice.

verses.text: When that year was ended, they came to him the following year and said, 'We cannot hide from my lord that our money is spent, the livestock are my lord’s. There is nothing left before my lord but our bodies and our lands.'
verses.comment: Their dependence foreshadows humanity’s complete surrender before God.

verses.text: 'Why should we die before your eyes, both we and our land? Buy us and our land for food, and we with our land will be servants to Pharaoh. Give us seed, so we may live and not die, and that the land may not become desolate.'
verses.comment: Here, service and submission are linked to salvation and provision—a motif persistent in Scripture (see Rom. 6:16).

verses.text: So Joseph bought all the land of Egypt for Pharaoh, for all the Egyptians sold their fields, because the famine was severe on them. The land became Pharaoh's.
verses.comment: Ultimate ownership of the land by Pharaoh reflects God’s ultimate sovereignty and the delegated authority of His chosen instruments.

verses.text: And as for the people, he made servants of them from one end of Egypt to the other.
verses.comment: This verse points ahead to later biblical reflections on servanthood and freedom. True freedom is not merely release from servitude, but belonging to God (John 8:36).

verses.text: Only the land of the priests he did not buy, for the priests had a fixed share from Pharaoh; they lived off the allocation that Pharaoh gave them. Therefore they did not sell their land.
verses.comment: Priestly privilege can be compared to later traditions where those who serve God are specially provided for by the community.

verses.text: Then Joseph said to the people, 'Behold, today I have bought you and your land for Pharaoh. Here is seed for you, and you shall sow the land.'
verses.comment: Seed given to the people ensures life and future harvest—a biblical symbol pointing to spiritual rebirth (Mark 4:14).

verses.text: 'And at the harvest you shall give a fifth to Pharaoh, and four fifths shall be your own, as seed for the field and as food for yourselves and your households, and as food for your little ones.'
verses.comment: Joseph institutes a system of return, reflecting obligation and gratitude to the giver. The principle of giving back is foundational and endures throughout Scripture.

verses.text: And they said, 'You have saved our lives; may we find favor in the sight of my lord, and we will be servants to Pharaoh.'
verses.comment: Acknowledging being saved through servanthood subtly points to salvation that comes through surrender and faithful service.

verses.text: So Joseph made it a statute over the land of Egypt to this day, that Pharaoh should have the fifth; only the land of the priests did not become Pharaoh’s.
verses.comment: A lasting statute and a perpetual principle; the idea of a set-apart portion continues in Scripture with offerings and tithes (Lev. 27:30).

verses.text: Thus Israel settled in the land of Egypt, in the land of Goshen. And they gained possessions in it, and were fruitful and multiplied greatly.
verses.comment: The fruitfulness of Israel underlines God’s faithfulness to His promises, echoing Genesis 17:6 and pointing toward the growth of God’s people.

verses.text: And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt seventeen years. So the days of Jacob, the years of his life, were one hundred forty-seven years.
verses.comment: This verse sums up Jacob’s sojourn. The span of his life is marked by fulfillment and divine providence.

verses.text: When the time drew near for Israel to die, he called his son Joseph and said to him, 'If I have found favor in your sight, put your hand under my thigh, and deal with me in faithfulness and truth. Do not bury me in Egypt.'
verses.comment: The Hebrew custom of oath-taking highlights the seriousness of this request. Jacob’s desire points to the anticipation of the promised land.

verses.text: 'But when I lie down with my fathers, you shall carry me out of Egypt and bury me in their burial place.' Joseph answered, 'I will do as you have said.'
verses.comment: Jacob’s instructions reinforce the unity of the patriarchs and the importance of a sacred burial—anticipating resurrection hope.

verses.text: And he said, 'Swear to me.' And he swore to him. Then Israel bowed himself upon the head of his bed.
verses.comment: Jacob’s act of bowing is an act of worship and thanksgiving, entrusting all to God’s promises. This act is referenced in Hebrews as the model of faith.
